channel.title: Switching to Computer (which program to go with?)
channel.description: Hey, I'm switching to Mac and I am not sure which music program to go with. I don't even really know what I'm looking for. (Prices don't scare me, I've dropped hundreds and hundreds of dollars on music in the past.)

item.title: Switching to Computer (which program to go with?)
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
It stands to Reason that whatever it is has a pretty tightly integrated app ecosystem and also finally supports VSTs since hell froze over apparently

Read full topic

item.title: Switching to Computer (which program to go with?)
item.dc:creator: Norfleet
item.description:
iammane:

FL is ok

FL’s definitely good, but it’s not completely out for Mac yet (it’s currently in beta testing). You can get it with Bootcamp (Use Windows on a Mac). They explain it better than I do: Is FL Studio available for Mac - macOS ?

Read full topic
item.source: Switching to Computer (which program to go with?)

item.title: Switching to Computer (which program to go with?)
item.dc:creator: Xiejra
item.description:
Then you learn the DAW? isnt that what you are supposed to do. besides the ammount of features you get with suite edition. better than FL or Logic imo. as well as this having the intro would be useful for people who are starting out. (even then I would recommend getting the full features so you dont have to spend more in the long run) if you want to upgrade you would spend more in the long run.

For someone who wants to go more professional into music either pursuing music as a carrer either in production or sound engineering I would propose getting a full studio to higher your experience. Ableton instruments are good cause they just work really well along with being not overly expensive either, because of their simplistic view it would really strip the learners experience doen to the fundamentals which encourages them to explore new sounds. It may be expensive but It would be worth it.

this is what I think anyway.

Read full topic

item.source: Switching to Computer (which program to go with?)

item.title: Switching to Computer (which program to go with?)
item.dc:creator: foryou
item.description:
yo just get ableton, it’s a lot easier to use than logic imo, but as it says above, the ableton instruments are horrible… honestly there’s not a lot that the suite version does that’s essential to making music… i have the intro version and it works just fine. focus more of your money on the vsts that you get such as serum and sylenth. those two are probably the best. nexus and avenger are good too but since you can’t really make your own presets, the presets the company gives out are overused

Read full topic
item.source: Switching to Computer (which program to go with?)

item.title: Switching to Computer (which program to go with?)
item.dc:creator: TheRealJFalc
item.description:
iammane:

It’s definitely not WHICH tool. It’s how someone uses it and how it fits their workflow for sure

Absolutely agreed on this. I feel that FL studio is a good transition from Auxy, but there possibly are other DAWs that work much better than it. It all depends on what works for you. (Also bias since I’m using FL studio but bleh)

If you’re going for a computer DAW (outside of Garageband, one that has VST compatability), I’d highly recommend obtaining the Serum wavetable synthesizer. It’s excellent and is great for designing sounds.

Read full topic

item.description:
They do enough, but Logic’s instruments do more. Analog and Operator don’t hold up against Alchemy or ES2, especially when you consider it costs 750 dollars for the Suite Version which includes these instruments but Logic has only one 200 dollar version.

Operator is easily my favourite FM synth and Wavetable looks brilliant.

Fwiw, if I had to pick one DAW, I’d go with Ableton.

item.title: Switching to Computer (which program to go with?)
item.dc:creator: XLXK
item.description:
Very Much Reccomend Ableton Live! It’s very easy and smart, a more complex version of Auxy I could say. I’d use Ableton Live but I have FL Studio. Anyways, you could use the free demo of Ableton, it won’t save projects but that helps you get more familiar with the software, besides, the first few things you make probably won’t be that good.

item.title: Switching to Computer (which program to go with?)
item.dc:creator: Pinewoodog
item.description:
I’ve never actually used it for DJing, so I’ll just take your word for it. I said that because Ableton advertised it that way, even though I’ve never DJayed once in my life.

item.source: Switching to Computer (which program to go with?)

item.title: Switching to Computer (which program to go with?)
item.dc:creator: NickElle
item.description:
I agree with all your points except for the Session View, which is the “clip view.”
It’s actually not DJing. I know Ableton says it’s for DJing, but it’s actually for a Live PA (Live Production Act).

Ps. You “can” actually DJ on Ableton, but it sucks. I would suggest Traktor, or Serato for DJing.

Read full topic

item.source: Switching to Computer (which program to go with?)

item.title: Switching to Computer (which program to go with?)
item.dc:creator: Pinewoodog
item.description:
I also have a Mac, and I have used both LPX and Ableton Live 9 Standard. When I was looking for a good Mac software I did a lot of research, so I’m pretty familiar with the top DAWs and top plugins.

I put together a list of the pros and cons of the top 2 DAWs for Mac; Logic Pro X and Ableton Live.

Logic Pro X:
Pros:
Easy to learn
Plenty of features
Amazing in-built synths
Tons of samples
Worth your money

Cons:
Difficult MIDI programming without a keyboard
Mac Only
64 bit plugin support only
Tough and confusing Automation

Ableton Live:
Pros:
Great workflow
Easy drum programming with “drum rack”
Amazing in-built effects
32 and 64 bit plugin support
Session View for LPA and smoother creation
Super easy Automation

Cons:
Steep Learning Curve
More Expensive
Doesn’t come with “good” in-built synths

Read full topic
item.source: Switching to Computer (which program to go with?)

item.title: Switching to Computer (which program to go with?)
item.dc:creator: blakkaz
item.description:
Shepdoge:

Edit: simple googley search reveals that Logic Pro is for P R O F E S S I O N A L S as it is $199, whereas GB is free. As such I’d go Logic Pro if you’re good to spend a bit more and dodge GB all together lol

That pretty much sums it up.

Garageband is more than enough to make professional music, but Logic has a much nicer workflow.

Read full topic

item.title: Switching to Computer (which program to go with?)
item.dc:creator: Shepdoge
item.description:
What is the relationship between Logic Pro and Garageband, or their differences/advantages and disadvantages?

Edit: simple googley search reveals that Logic Pro is for P R O F E S S I O N A L S as it is $199, whereas GB is free. As such I’d go Logic Pro if you’re good to spend a bit more and dodge GB all together lol
